Polo-like kinase-1 (Plk1) performs multiple essential functions during the cell cycle. Here we show that human Plk1-deficient cells are unable to separate their centrosomes, fail to form a bipolar spindle, and undergo a Mad2/BubR1-dependent prometaphase arrest. However, electron microscopy demonstrates that kinetochore-microtubule interactions can be established in cells lacking Plk1. In addition, co-depletion of Plk1 and survivin allows mitotic exit. This indicates that Plk1 depletion does not prevent microtubule attachment, but specifically interferes with the generation of tension, as a consequence of a failure to form a bipolar spindle. Moreover, we find that after silencing of the spindle assembly checkpoint, degradation of cyclin B1 is unaffected in cells lacking Plk1. These data indicate that activation of the anaphase promoting complex or cyclosome (APC/C)-Cdc20 complex that is under control of the spindle assembly checkpoint does not require Plk1 activity. Finally, we find that translocation of chromosome passengers and initiation of cleavage furrow ingression is unaffected in cells depleted of Plk1. Thus, our data confirm an important role of Plk1 in bipolar spindle formation, and also demonstrate that Plk1 is dispensable for APC/C-Cdc20 activation and the initiation of cytokinesis. Polo-like kinase-1 (Plk1) performs multiple essential functions during the cell cycle. Here we show that human Plk1-deficient cells are unable to separate their centrosomes, fail to form a bipolar spindle, and undergo a Mad2/BubR1-dependent prometaphase arrest. However, electron microscopy demonstrates that kinetochore-microtubule interactions can be established in cells lacking Plk1. In addition, co-depletion of Plk1 and survivin allows mitotic exit. This indicates that Plk1 depletion does not prevent microtubule attachment, but specifically interferes with the generation of tension, as a consequence of a failure to form a bipolar spindle. Moreover, we find that after silencing of the spindle assembly checkpoint, degradation of cyclin B1 is unaffected in cells lacking Plk1. These data indicate that activation of the anaphase promoting complex or cyclosome (APC/C)-Cdc20 complex that is under control of the spindle assembly checkpoint does not require Plk1 activity. Finally, we find that translocation of chromosome passengers and initiation of cleavage furrow ingression is unaffected in cells depleted of Plk1. Thus, our data confirm an important role of Plk1 in bipolar spindle formation, and also demonstrate that Plk1 is dispensable for APC/C-Cdc20 activation and the initiation of cytokinesis. Polo-like kinases have been associated with many aspects of mitosis (reviewed in Refs. 1Donaldson M.M. Tavares A.A. Hagan I.M. Nigg E.A. Glover D.M. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 2357-2358Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Glover D.M. Ohkura H. Tavares A. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 135: 1681-1684Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 3Glover D.M. Hagan I.M. Tavares A.A. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 3777-3787Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar, 4Nigg E.A. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1998; 10: 776-783Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar). Originally identified as the polo gene in Drosophila, Polo-like kinases were shown to be required for proper mitotic progression in various species. Whereas a single Polo-like kinase has been identified in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Cdc5), Schizosaccharomyces pombe (Plo1), and Drosophila melanogaster (Polo), mammalian cells appear to express up to four distinct Polo-like kinases (Plk1, Plk2 or SNK, Plk3 or Prk/Fnk, and SAK) (4Nigg E.A. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1998; 10: 776-783Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar). Of these different kinases, the function of Plk1 is most extensively studied, and Plk1 appears to play multiple important roles during mitosis (1Donaldson M.M. Tavares A.A. Hagan I.M. Nigg E.A. Glover D.M. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 2357-2358Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). At the G2-M transition, a role for Polo-like kinases was suggested in activation of the cyclin B1-Cdk1 complex. Experiments in Xenopus extracts showed that the Polo orthologue Plx1 is able to phosphorylate and activate the Cdc25C phosphatase (5Kumagai A. Dunphy W.G. Science. 1996; 273: 1377-1380Crossref PubMed Scopus (468) Google Scholar, 6Qian Y.W. Erikson E. Taieb F.E. Maller J.L. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2001; 12: 1791-1799Crossref PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). Cdc25C in turn activates the Cdk1 subunit of the cyclin B1-Cdk1 complex by dephosphorylation (reviewed in Ref. 7Smits V.A. Medema R.H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2001; 1519: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (302) Google Scholar). Cyclin B1-Cdk1 complexes can phosphorylate and further activate Cdc25C (8Hoffmann I. Clarke P.R. Marcote M.J. Karsenti E. Draetta G. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 53-63Crossref PubMed Scopus (560) Google Scholar, 9Izumi T. Maller J.L. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 1337-1350Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar), resulting in a positive feedback loop that facilitates rapid entry into mitosis. In addition, active Plk1 was shown to induce translocation of both Cdc25C and cyclin B1 to the nucleus (10Toyoshima-Morimoto F. Taniguchi E. Shinya N. Iwamatsu A. Nishida E. Nature. 2001; 410: 215-220Crossref PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar, 11Toyoshima-Morimoto F. Taniguchi E. Nishida E. EMBO Rep. 2002; 3: 341-348Crossref PubMed Scopus (267) Google Scholar). More recent work, however, indicates that Plk1-mediated phosphorylation does not cause cyclin B1 to move into the nucleus, but suggests it rather contributes to activation of cyclin B1-Cdk complexes at the centrosomes (12Jackman M. Lindon C. Nigg E.A. Pines J. Nat. Cell Biol. 2003; 5: 143-148Crossref PubMed Scopus (487) Google Scholar). During the early stages of mitosis, Polo-like kinases were shown to mediate the displacement of cohesin from the chromosome arms by phosphorylating the cohesin subunit SCC1 (13Losada A. Hirano M. Hirano T. Genes Dev. 2002; 16: 3004-3016Crossref PubMed Scopus (281) Google Scholar, 14Sumara I. Vorlaufer E. Stukenberg P.T. Kelm O. Redemann N. Nigg E.A. Peters J.M. Mol. Cell. 2002; 9: 515-525Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar). The cohesin complex holds paired chromatids together and plays a central role in ensuring that paired sister chromatids obtain bipolar attachment prior to segregation of the chromosomes to opposite poles during anaphase (15Nasmyth K. Peters J.M. Uhlmann F. Science. 2000; 288: 1379-1385Crossref PubMed Scopus (376) Google Scholar). During prophase in vertebrates (but not in yeast), cohesin is displaced from the chromosome arms, whereas it is specifically retained at the centromeric region (16Waizenegger I.C. Hauf S. Meinke A. Peters J.M. Cell. 2000; 103: 399-410Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (567) Google Scholar). SCC1 phosphorylation by Plx1 strongly decreases the binding capacity of cohesin to chromatin and was shown to be required and sufficient to drive cohesin displacement from the chromosome arms (14Sumara I. Vorlaufer E. Stukenberg P.T. Kelm O. Redemann N. Nigg E.A. Peters J.M. Mol. Cell. 2002; 9: 515-525Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar). Removal of the centromeric fraction of cohesin at the metaphase-to-anaphase transition requires activation of a ubiquitin ligase called the anaphase promoting complex or cyclosome (APC/C) 1The abbreviations used are: APC/C, anaphase promoting complex or cyclosome; siRNA, small interfering RNA; RNAi, RNA interference; CFP, cyan fluorescent protein; YFP, yellow fluorescent protein; GFP, green fluorescent protein; DIC, differential interference contrast; Pipes, 1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; INCENP, inner centromere protein; PI, propidium iodide; FACS, fluorescence-activated cell sorting.1The abbreviations used are: APC/C, anaphase promoting complex or cyclosome; siRNA, small interfering RNA; RNAi, RNA interference; CFP, cyan fluorescent protein; YFP, yellow fluorescent protein; GFP, green fluorescent protein; DIC, differential interference contrast; Pipes, 1,4-piperazinediethanesulfonic acid; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; INCENP, inner centromere protein; PI, propidium iodide; FACS, fluorescence-activated cell sorting. (17Hauf S. Waizenegger I.C. Peters J.M. Science. 2001; 293: 1320-1323Crossref PubMed Scopus (371) Google Scholar). Active APC/C mediates degradation of securin, an inhibitor of cohesin cleavage (18Zou H. McGarry T.J. Bernal T. Kirschner M.W. Science. 1999; 285: 418-422Crossref PubMed Scopus (672) Google Scholar). Degradation of securin, but also of cyclin A and cyclin B1, requires association of APC/C with the regulatory subunit Cdc20 (19Peters J.M. Exp. Cell Res. 1999; 248: 339-349Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). Later in mitosis, association of the APC/C with the Cdc20-related protein Cdh1 is required for degradation of other mitotic proteins, such as Aurora A and Cdc20. In the process of APC/C activation, Plk1 was suggested to play a regulatory role. Plk1 has been shown to phosphorylate three subunits of the APC/C in vitro (Cdc16, Cdc27, and Tsg24) (20Kotani S. Tugendreich S. Fujii M. Jorgensen P.M. Watanabe N. Hoog C. Hieter P. Todokoro K. Mol. Cell. 1998; 1: 371-380Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (280) Google Scholar, 21Golan A. Yudkovsky Y. Hershko A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 15552-15557Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar). In addition, depletion of Plx1 from Xenopus extracts was shown to block APC/C-dependent degradation of cyclin B (22Descombes P. Nigg E.A. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 1328-1335Crossref PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar). However, controversy remains whether cyclin B1-Cdk1 or Plk1 acts as the major APC/C-activating kinase, as mutational analysis in budding yeast APC/C subunits pointed at cyclin B1-Cdk1 as the predominant APC/C activator in vivo (23Rudner A.D. Murray A.W. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 149: 1377-1390Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). Polo-like kinases also perform essential roles during the later stages of mitosis. In fission yeast, disruption of the plo1 gene leads to failure in septum formation, a process that is homologous to cytokinesis in mammalian cells (24Ohkura H. Hagan I.M. Glover D.M. Genes Dev. 1995; 9: 1059-1073Crossref PubMed Scopus (326) Google Scholar). Loss of plo1 protein resulted in failure to form an F-actin ring as well as loss of septal protein accumulation, whereas overexpression of plo1 could drive excessive septum formation. Similarly, in budding yeast, the Polo-like kinase Cdc5 has been shown to trigger activation of the mitotic exit network by inducing release of the Cdc14 phosphatase from the nucleolus (25Hu F. Wang Y. Liu D. Li Y. Qin J. Elledge S.J. Cell. 2001; 107: 655-665Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar, 26Stegmeier F. Visintin R. Amon A. Cell. 2002; 108: 207-220Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (364) Google Scholar). Release of Cdc14 causes the activation of the APC/C-Cdh1, accumulation of the Cdk inhibitor SIC1 and ultimately results to the inactivation of mitotic cyclins, a prerequisite for mitotic exit and cytokinesis (27Bardin A.J. Amon A. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 2: 815-826Crossref PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar). A role for Polo kinases in cytokinesis in mammalian cells was also suggested, based on experiments in which overexpression of a dominant negative mutant of Plk1 was used to interfere with the function of Plk1 (28Seong Y.S. Kamijo K. Lee J.S. Fernandez E. Kuriyama R. Miki T. Lee K.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 32282-32293Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). After inactivation of the spindle assembly checkpoint, expression of this fragment did not allow successful cytokinesis and resulted in formation of binucleated cells. In addition, recent observations suggested that phosphorylation of Mklp2 and Nir2 by Plk1 is required for proper cytokinesis (29Litvak V. Argov R. Dahan N. Ramachandran S. Amarilio R. Shainskaya A. Lev S. Mol. Cell. 2004; 14: 319-330Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar, 30Neef R. Preisinger C. Sutcliffe J. Kopajtich R. Nigg E.A. Mayer T.U. Barr F.A. J. Cell Biol. 2003; 162: 863-875Crossref PubMed Scopus (253) Google Scholar). Finally, regulatory roles for Plk1 in the centrosome cycle and formation of the mitotic spindle have been reported in a variety of species (reviewed in Refs. 1Donaldson M.M. Tavares A.A. Hagan I.M. Nigg E.A. Glover D.M. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 2357-2358Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Glover D.M. Ohkura H. Tavares A. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 135: 1681-1684Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 3Glover D.M. Hagan I.M. Tavares A.A. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 3777-3787Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar, 4Nigg E.A. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1998; 10: 776-783Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar). In Drosophila, Polo was shown to phosphorylate Asp, a microtubule-associated protein that binds to the centrosomes and is required to organize microtubule asters (31Gonzalez C. Sunkel C.E. Glover D.M. Chromosoma. 1998; 107: 452-460Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 32do Carmo Avides M. Tavares A. Glover D.M. Nat. Cell Biol. 2001; 3: 421-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). Mutations in Polo result in the formation of aberrant mitotic spindles and disrupt centrosome organization (33Llamazares S. Moreira A. Tavares A. Girdham C. Spruce B.A. Gonzalez C. Karess R.E. Glover D.M. Sunkel C.E. Genes Dev. 1991; 5: 2153-2165Crossref PubMed Scopus (333) Google Scholar, 34Sunkel C.E. Glover D.M. J. Cell Sci. 1988; 89: 25-38Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In HeLa cells, microinjection of neutralizing anti-Plk1-antibodies impaired centrosome maturation and resulted in a mitotic arrest (35Lane H.A. Nigg E.A. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 135: 1701-1713Crossref PubMed Scopus (594) Google Scholar). Similar results were obtained in Xenopus extracts, where cells that do not require activation of Cdc25C for mitotic entry were shown to arrest in mitosis with monopolar spindles, when Plx1 was depleted (36Qian Y.W. Erikson E. Li C. Maller J.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 4262-4271Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar). More recently, interference with Plk1 expression was shown to impair the ability of centrosomes to amplify in a hydroxyurea block (37Liu X. Erikson R.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 8672-8676Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar). At present, it is unclear how the multiple functions of Plk1 are separated in space and time to allow orderly progression through the different stages of mitosis. In addition, it is not exactly clear whether all of the reported cell cycle defects are a direct consequence of interference with Plk1 function, or whether they arise as a secondary effect of a spindle defect or aberrant entry into mitosis. To gain more insight on the diverse functions of Plk1 during division of human cells, we examined the roles of Plk1 by RNA interference. Cell Culture, Synchronization, and Spindle Assembly Checkpoint Activation—Experiments were performed in U2OS and HeLa cells grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 6% fetal calf serum, 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100 μg/ml streptomycin. For cell synchronization at the G1/S transition, cells were incubated with 2.5 mm thymidine for 24 h. To block centrosome separation, 200 μm monastrol was added directly after thymidine release, if indicated. To arrest cells at the spindle assembly checkpoint, paclitaxel (1 μg/ml) was added directly after release from the thymidine block where indicated. Mitotic HeLa cells were obtained by shake-off at 24 h after thymidine release. G2 HeLa cells were obtained at 6 h after thymidine release. All drugs were obtained from Sigma. Transfections and Colony Formation Assays—Cells were transfected by the standard calcium phosphate transfection protocol. Where indicated, cells were synchronized by a thymidine block directly after washing away the calcium phosphate precipitate. Cells were maintained in thymidine for 24 h, after which they were released from the block, and followed as they progressed through S-, G2-, and M-phase. At different time points after release, cells were harvested and analyzed by flow cytometry or immunofluorescence. Alternatively, transfected cells were monitored by time-lapse analysis. For colony formation assays or selection of transfected cells, 0.5 μg of pBabePuro was co-transfected with 10 μg of pSuper or pS-Plk1. 48 h after transfection, cells were collected by trypsinization and harvested. For colony formation assays, equal amounts of transfected cells were plated on 10-cm dishes and selected with 2 μg/ml puromycin for 10–14 days. At this point, cells were fixed in methanol and colonies were stained with crystal violet. Time-lapse Analysis—Cells were plated on 35-mm glass-bottom culture dishes (Willco-dish, Amsterdam, The Netherlands) and transfected the next day with pSuper or pS-Plk1, in combination with H2B-GFP. After release from thymidine block, cells were followed by time-lapse microscopy starting at ∼10 h after release. More than 80% of the cells were in late G2 at this point, as determined in parallel experiments using flow cytometry. For live imaging, dishes were transferred to a heated culture chamber (37 °C, 5% CO2) of a Zeiss Axiovert 200M microscope equipped with a 0.55 numeric aperture condenser and a 40× Plan-Neo DIC objective (numeric aperture = 1.3). 12-bit phase contrast images (100-ms exposures to halogen light) and green fluorescence (100-ms exposures to blue light) were captured using a Photometrics Coolsnap HQ charged-coupled device camera set at gain 1.0 (Scientific, Tucson, AZ) and a GFP/DsRed or CFP/YFP dual band pass filter set (Chroma Technology Corp. Rockingham, VT) to select specific fluorescence. Images were processed using MetaMorph software (Universal Imaging, Downington, PA). Flow Cytometry—MPM2 positivity of transfected cells was determined as described (41Smits V.A. Klompmaker R. Arnaud L. Rijksen G. Nigg E.A. Medema R.H. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 672-676Crossref PubMed Scopus (392) Google Scholar). For analysis of phosphohistone H3 positivity, cells were harvested at the indicated time points after release from a thymidine block and fixed in ice-cold 70% ethanol. Cells were washed once with PBS containing 0.05% Tween 20 and stained with anti-phosphohistone H3 antibody. Cells were subsequently stained with a Cy5-conjugated anti-rabbit antibody and counterstained with propidium iodide. Cell cycle distribution of the transfected (GFP-positive) cells was analyzed using flow cytometry (Cell Quest, Becton Dickinson) as described (41Smits V.A. Klompmaker R. Arnaud L. Rijksen G. Nigg E.A. Medema R.H. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 672-676Crossref PubMed Scopus (392) Google Scholar). Electron Microscopy—U2OS were transfected with 10 μg of pSuper or pS-Plk1. After release from a thymidine block, pSuper-transfected cells were treated with paclitaxel (1 mg/ml). 24 h after thymidine release, mitotic cells were obtained by gentle shake-off, fixed in 2.5% glutaraldehyde in PHEM (60 mm Pipes, 25 mm Hepes, 2 mm MgCl2, and 10 mm EGTA, pH 6.9) for 2 h, and postfixed for 1 h with 2% osmium tetroxide. Then they were treated for 1 min with 0.15% tannic acid, stained en bloc with 1% uranyl acetate, dehydrated, and embedded in LX-112. Thin sections were examined with a CM10 transmission electron microscope (Philips, Eindhoven, The Netherlands). Immunofluorescence—Cells were grown on coverslips coated by incubation in 10% poly-l-lysine (Sigma) for 1 h. Cells were transfected the next day and synchronized using thymidine. At the indicated time points after thymidine release from the block, coverslips were removed from the culture dish and washed twice with PBS. Cells were then fixed for 10 min in 3.7% paraformaldehyde at room temperature and subsequently washed with PBS (twice). Alternatively, for α-tubulin and γ-tubulin staining, coverslips were washed in PBS, permeabilized with 0.5% Triton X-100 for 0.5 min in PHEM buffer (45 mm Pipes, 45 mm Hepes, 10 mm EGTA, 5 mm MgCl2, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, pH 6.8). Cells were then fixed in 3.7% formaldehyde for 10 min, followed by fixation in ice-cold methanol. For measurement of γ-tubulin intensity of coverslips containing pS- or pS-Plk1-transfected cells, Leica software was used to segment γ-tubulin associated with centrosomes by thresholding. Images were binarized and multiplied with original images to obtain 8-bit scale at segmented areas (Leica Microsystems, Heidelberg, Germany). As a control, neighboring nontransfected cells were analyzed and showed similar γ-tubulin intensity as pS-transfected cells. For Mad2 and BubR1 staining, cells were permeabilized in sucrose buffer (20 mm Tris, 50 mm NaCl, 300 mm sucrose, 3 mm MgCl2, pH 7.4), prior to staining. Cells were analyzed on a Leica DMIRBE confocal microscope equipped with a 63× objective. Plk1 Is Essential for Progression through Mitosis—We used siRNA to specifically deplete Plk1 from human cells. For this purpose, we used pSuper, which allows stable expression of siRNAs in transfected cells (38Brummelkamp T.R. Bernards R. Agami R. Science. 2002; 296: 550-553Crossref PubMed Scopus (3928) Google Scholar). Co-transfection of our Plk1 targeting vector (pS-Plk1) with an expression vector encoding myc-tagged Plk1 in U2OS human osteosarcoma cells resulted in a dramatic reduction of myc-Plk1 expression (Fig. 1A). This was further confirmed by performing in vitro kinase assays in which the ectopically expressed myc-tagged Plk1 was specifically immunoprecipitated, allowing us to quantify the extent of down-regulation. Using this approach, we determined the reduction in Plk1 expression by transfection of pS-Plk1 to be greater than 95% (Fig. 1A). To analyze whether expression of endogenous Plk1 was equally sensitive to expression of pS-Plk1, we selected puromycin-resistant cells after co-transfection of a puromycin resistance marker. This confirmed that the pS-Plk1 targeting vector effectively down-regulated expression of endogenous Plk1 (Fig. 1B). To study the general requirement for Plk1 for human cell division, we performed cell cycle analysis specifically on the transfected populations. We found that Plk1-depleted cells accumulated with a 4 N DNA content, indicating that these cells arrest either in G2 or in mitosis (Fig. 1C). As is shown in Fig. 1C, at 48 h after transfection ∼24% of pS-Plk1-transfected cells arrested in mitosis, as evidenced by a sharp increase in histone H3 phosphorylation. This is approximately half of the amount of mitotic cells we obtain after a 24-h treatment of U2OS cells with paclitaxel, indicating that a large fraction of the Plk1-depleted cells arrest in mitosis. Similar results were obtained when we analyzed the appearance of MPM-2 positivity, another well established mitotic marker (46Davis F.M. Tsao T.Y. Fowler S.K. Rao P.N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 2926-2930Crossref PubMed Scopus (499) Google Scholar), or scored mitotic indices by immunofluorescence microscopy of PI-stained cells (data not shown). To prove that the pS-Plk1 targeting vector is specific, we reintroduced Plk1 into Plk1-depleted cells. For this purpose, we introduced two silent mutations in the part of the coding region of Plk1 that is recognized by the Plk1 siRNA. The expression of such a silent mutant of Plk1 (Plk1-sil) is unaffected by pS-Plk1 (Fig. 1D), showing that this silent mutant of Plk1 can be used to reconstitute expression of functional Plk1 in cells depleted of endogenous Plk1. Importantly, expression of Plk1-sil reverted the mitotic arrest that was observed with pS-Plk1 (Fig. 1C). In contrast, expression of a kinase-defective Plk1 mutant (Plk1-sil-KD) did not revert the mitotic arrest, showing that the kinase activity of Plk1 is crucial for its mitotic function. Stable expression of Plk1 siRNA in U2OS osteosarcoma cells led to a complete inhibition of colony formation, indicating that Plk1 has an essential role in cell proliferation that precludes the establishment of cell lines that lack Plk1 (Fig. 1E). These results are in line with the previously described loss of cell proliferation after Plk1 depletion (47Spankuch-Schmitt B. Wolf G. Solbach C. Loibl S. Knecht R. Stegmuller M. von Minckwitz G. Kaufmann M. Strebhardt K. Oncogene. 2002; 21: 3162-3171Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). Cell Cycle Progression after Plk1 Depletion—Plk1 has been suggested to play an important role in the activation of Cdc25C and in the nuclear translocation of both cyclin B1 as well as Cdc25C. This would suggest that Plk1 is essential for mitotic entry. We therefore analyzed cell cycle progression of the Plk1-knockdown cells in a synchronized cell population. Cells were maintained in thymidine for 24 h to block them at the G1-S transition, after which they were released and followed as they progressed through the cell cycle. Whereas control cultures progressed to the subsequent G1 phase at ∼18 h after thymidine release, Plk1-depleted cells failed to complete the cell cycle and arrested with 4 N DNA content (Fig. 2A). As judged from the clear accumulation of phosphohistone H3, Plk1 knockdown cells arrested in mitosis (Fig. 2B). Detailed analysis of the timing of mitotic entry showed that the majority of cells depleted of Plk1 entered mitosis with similar kinetics as control cells, indicating that Plk1 does not play an essential role in mitotic entry. 3van Vugt, M. A. T. M., Bras, A., and Medema, R

The purpose of this study was to determine the role of NADPH oxidase in H+ secretion by airway epithelia. In whole cell patch clamp recordings primary human tracheal epithelial cells (hTE) and the human serous gland cell line Calu-3 expressed a functionally similar zincblockable plasma membrane H+ conductance. However, the rate of H+ secretion of confluent epithelial monolayers measured in Ussing chambers was 9-fold larger in hTE compared with Calu-3. In hTE H+ secretion was blocked by mucosal ZnCl2 and the NADPH oxidase blockers acetovanillone and 4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl fluoride (AEBSF), whereas these same blockers had no effect in Calu-3. We determined levels of transcripts for the NADPH oxidase transmembrane isoforms (Nox1 through -5, Duox1 and -2, and p22phox) and found Duox1, -2, and p22phox to be highly expressed in hTE, as well as the intracellular subunits p40phox, p47phox, and p67phox. In contrast, Calu-3 lacked transcripts for Duox1, p40phox, and p47phox. Anti-Duox antibody staining resulted in prominent apical staining in hTE but no significant staining in Calu-3. When treated with amiloride to block the Na+/H+ exchanger, intracellular pH in hTE acidified at significantly higher rates than in Calu-3, and treatment with AEBSF blocked acidification. These data suggest a role for an apically located Duox-based NADPH oxidase during intracellular H+ production and H+ secretion, but not in H+ conduction. The purpose of this study was to determine the role of NADPH oxidase in H+ secretion by airway epithelia. In whole cell patch clamp recordings primary human tracheal epithelial cells (hTE) and the human serous gland cell line Calu-3 expressed a functionally similar zincblockable plasma membrane H+ conductance. However, the rate of H+ secretion of confluent epithelial monolayers measured in Ussing chambers was 9-fold larger in hTE compared with Calu-3. In hTE H+ secretion was blocked by mucosal ZnCl2 and the NADPH oxidase blockers acetovanillone and 4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl fluoride (AEBSF), whereas these same blockers had no effect in Calu-3. We determined levels of transcripts for the NADPH oxidase transmembrane isoforms (Nox1 through -5, Duox1 and -2, and p22phox) and found Duox1, -2, and p22phox to be highly expressed in hTE, as well as the intracellular subunits p40phox, p47phox, and p67phox. In contrast, Calu-3 lacked transcripts for Duox1, p40phox, and p47phox. Anti-Duox antibody staining resulted in prominent apical staining in hTE but no significant staining in Calu-3. When treated with amiloride to block the Na+/H+ exchanger, intracellular pH in hTE acidified at significantly higher rates than in Calu-3, and treatment with AEBSF blocked acidification. These data suggest a role for an apically located Duox-based NADPH oxidase during intracellular H+ production and H+ secretion, but not in H+ conduction. Boucher R.C. J. Clin. Invest. 2002; 109: 571-577Crossref PubMed Scopus (933) Google Scholar). Recently, considerable attention has focused on the pH of the ASL (pHASL), which has been shown to affect various epithelial functions such as ion transport (2Konstas A.A. Mavrelos D. Korbmacher C. Pflugers Arch. 2000; 441: 341-350Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 3Chalfant M.L. Denton J.S. Berdiev B.K. Ismailov I.I. Benos D.J. Stanton B.A. Am. J. Physiol. 1999; 276: C477-C486Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), ciliary beating (4Clary-Meinesz C. Mouroux J. Cosson J. Huitorel P. Blaive B. Eur. Respir. J. 1998; 11: 330-333Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 5Luk C.K. Dulfano M.J. Clin. Sci. 1983; 64: 449-451Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar), and epithelial integrity (6Giddens W.E. Fairchild G.A. Arch. Environ. Health. 1972; 25: 166-173Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 7Holma B. Lindegren M. Markholdt Anderson J. Arch. Environ. Health. 1977; 32: 216-226Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar). pHASL has been found to be slightly acidic compared with plasma. Initially, pHASL in the ferret trachea was found to be 6.85 using microelectrode measurements (8Kyle H. Ward J.P. Widdicombe J.G. J. Appl. Physiol. 1990; 68: 135-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). Using a pH-sensitive fluorophore, pHASL was found to be 6.8 in bovine cultures and 7.1 in vivo in mice (9Jayaraman S. Song Y. Verkman A.S. Am. J. Physiol. 2001; 281: C1504-C1511Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In the inflammatory airway diseases asthma, cystic fibrosis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease an acidic pHASL or acidic exhaled breath has been demonstrated (10Hunt J.F. Fang K. Malik R. Snyder A. Malhotra N. Platts-Mills T.A.E. Gaston B. Am. J. Respir. Crit. Care Med. 2000; 161: 694-699Crossref PubMed Scopus (601) Google Scholar, 11Kostikas K. Papatheodorou G. Ganas K. Psathakis K. Panagou P. Loukides S. Am. J. Respir. Crit. Care Med. 2002; 165: 1364-1370Crossref PubMed Scopus (387) Google Scholar, 12Coakley R.D. Grubb B.R. Paradiso A.M. Gatzy J.T. Johnson L.G. Kreda S.M. O'Neal W.K. Boucher R.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 16083-16088Crossref PubMed Scopus (205) Google Scholar). These observations suggested a regulated mechanism of acid secretion by the airways that is up-regulated during inflammation. Recently we found that human airway cells express a voltage-activated, zinc-sensitive H+ conductance and secrete acidequivalents into the mucosal bath (13Fischer H. Widdicombe J.H. Illek B. Am. J. Physiol. 2002; 282: C736-C743Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). H+-selective, voltage-activated currents were first recorded from snail neurons (14Thomas R.C. Meech R.W. Nature. 1982; 299: 826-828Crossref PubMed Scopus (224) Google Scholar) and since then have been found in many other cell types (15DeCoursey T.E. Physiol. Rev. 2003; 83: 475-579Crossref PubMed Scopus (549) Google Scholar). The transmembrane protein complex NADPH oxidase has been suggested to mediate the H+ conductance in phagocytic cells (16Henderson L.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 33216-33223Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar), although this notion has been challenged recently (17Morgan D. Cherny V.V. Price M.O. Dinauer M.C. DeCoursey T.E. J. Gen. Physiol. 2002; 119: 571-580Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). In phagocytic cells NADPH oxidase plays a crucial role in killing invading organisms by producing superoxide radicals (O2·¯) by transferring an electron from intracellular NADPH across the membrane to extracellular O2. During the process of NADPH oxidation in neutrophils, intracellular H+ is released from NADPH and thereby contributes to intracellular acid production (18Demaurex N. Downey G.P. Waddell T.K. Grinstein S. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 133: 1391-1402Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). The phagocytic NADPH oxidase is a multisubunit enzyme consisting of two transmembrane subunits (the cytochrome gp91phox and p22phox), three cytosolic subunits (p40phox, p47phox, and p67phox), and a small ubiquitously expressed GTP-binding protein p21rac (19Shatwell K.P. Segal A.W. Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 1996; 28: 1191-1195Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). In phagocytes, all subunits were shown to be necessary for a regulated release of O2·¯ during the respiratory burst (20DeLeo F. Quinn M. J. Leukoc. Biol. 1996; 60: 677-691Crossref PubMed Scopus (455) Google Scholar). gp91phox is a member of the Nox gene family, where it is referred to as Nox2. In addition to the small Nox homologs Nox1 through -5, two large homologs have been described recently, called dual oxidases Duox1 and -2 (21Dupuy C. Ohayon R. Valent A. Noel-Hudson M.-S. Deme D. Virion A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 37265-37269Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (370) Google Scholar, 22De Deken X. Wang D. Many M.-C. Costagliola S. Libert F. Vassart G. Dumont J.E. Miot F. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 23227-23233Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (489) Google Scholar, 23Edens W.A. Sharling L. Cheng G. Shapira R. Kinkade J.M. Lee T. Edens H.A. Tang X. Sullards C. Flaherty D.B. Benian G.M. Lambeth J.D. J. Cell Biol. 2001; 154: 879-892Crossref PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar). Expression of Duox1 and -2 has been found in the epithelium of the thyroid gland by immunofluorescence (22De Deken X. Wang D. Many M.-C. Costagliola S. Libert F. Vassart G. Dumont J.E. Miot F. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 23227-23233Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (489) Google Scholar), and expression of Duox1 transcript by in situ hybridization and Duox1 antisense-sensitive H2O2 production by airway epithelial cultures has been demonstrated (24Geiszt M. Witta J. Baffi J. Lekstrom K. Leto T.L. FASEB J. 2003; 17: 1502-1504Crossref PubMed Scopus (406) Google Scholar). Recent studies in our laboratory identified a zinc-sensitive H+ conductance and H+ secretion across the apical membrane of well differentiated human airway epithelia (13Fischer H. Widdicombe J.H. Illek B. Am. J. Physiol. 2002; 282: C736-C743Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). We were intrigued by the notion that this physiological process was provided by the NADPH oxidase complex. This was addressed by studying H+ conductance, H+ secretion, NADPH oxidase expression, and intracellular H+ production in two functionally different types of human airway epithelia. Ciliated cells from the airway surface epithelium function to absorb fluid and acidify the airway lumen slightly (8Kyle H. Ward J.P. Widdicombe J.G. J. Appl. Physiol. 1990; 68: 135-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 9Jayaraman S. Song Y. Verkman A.S. Am. J. Physiol. 2001; 281: C1504-C1511Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 13Fischer H. Widdicombe J.H. Illek B. Am. J. Physiol. 2002; 282: C736-C743Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar), whereas cells from the submucosal serous glands secrete a bicarbonate-rich, alkaline fluid (25.Ballard, S. T., Trout, L., Bebok, Z., Sorscher, E. J., and Crews, A. (1999) 277, L694–L699Google Scholar, 26Lee M.C. Penland C.M. Widdicombe J.H. Wine J.J. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 274: L450-L453Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In this report we compare the properties of airway surface versus submucosal gland cells by using primary cultures of human tracheal surface epithelia (hTE) and the Calu-3 submucosal gland cell line. These cells were chosen to relate high (hTE) and low rates (Calu-3) of H+ secretion to the expression of NADPH oxidase and its function. The experiments in this report demonstrate the localization of the dual oxidase Duox in the apical membrane of hTE surface cells but not in Calu-3 gland cells. Our data suggest that a Duox-based NADPH oxidase complex supports epithelial H+ secretion by generating intracellular H+, which provides a H+ gradient across the apical cell membrane. The plasma membrane H+ conductance did not correlate with Duox expression suggesting that intracellular H+ exited through a parallel pathway. Cell Cultures—Human primary tracheal epithelial cultures (hTE) were isolated as previously described (27Yamaya M. Finkbeiner W.E. Chun S.Y. Widdicombe J.H. Am. J. Physiol. 1992; 262: L713-L724Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium:bronchial epithelial cell basal medium (1:1) as described by Gray et al. (28Gray T. Guzman K. Davis C. Abdullah L. Nettesheim P. Am. J. Respir. Cell Mol. Biol. 1996; 14: 104-112Crossref PubMed Scopus (407) Google Scholar). Compared with our previous report (13Fischer H. Widdicombe J.H. Illek B. Am. J. Physiol. 2002; 282: C736-C743Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar), this is a change in culture conditions, which resulted in epithelial cultures with significantly lower transepithelial resistances (Rt = 569 ± 36 Ω·cm2, n = 12) and higher potentials (Vt = –26.0 ± 2.1 mV). Sachs et al. described the effects of both culture conditions (29Sachs L.A. Finkbeiner W.E. Widdicombe J.H. In Vitro Cell Dev. Biol. Anim. 2003; 39: 56-62Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Calu-3 cells, a human airway cell line with characteristics of airway serous cells (30Shen B.Q. Finkbeiner W.E. Wine J.J. Mrsny R.J. Widdicombe J.H. Am. J. Physiol. 1994; 266: L493-L501PubMed Google Scholar), were grown in a Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium/F-12 mix supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum. For patch clamping or measurement of intracellular pH (pHi), cells were seeded on collagen-coated glass coverslips and used after 1–2 days. For transepithelial measurements and for biochemical assays, cells were grown on permeable filters (Snapwell, 0.4-μm pore size, 1-cm2 area; Corning Costar, Cambridge, MA) to confluency at an air-liquid interface. Confluent Calu-3 monolayers had Rt = 267 ± 34 Ω·cm2 and Vt = –5.6 ± 0.7 mV (n = 18). Some cultures were treated for 1 h with 100 μm ZnCl2 (mucosally) or for 14–16 h with the NADPH oxidase blockers 4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl fluoride (AEBSF, 500 μm (31Diatchuk V. Lotan O. Koshkin V. Wikstroem P. Pick E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 13292-13301Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar)) or acetovanillone (500 μm (32Stolk J. Hiltermann T. Dijkman J. Verhoeven A. Am. J. Respir. Cell Mol. Biol. 1994; 11: 95-102Crossref PubMed Scopus (576) Google Scholar)) in the cell culture medium. Whole Cell Patch Clamp Recordings—Cells were whole cell patchclamped as previously described (13Fischer H. Widdicombe J.H. Illek B. Am. J. Physiol. 2002; 282: C736-C743Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar, 33Illek B. Fischer H. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 275: L902-L910PubMed Google Scholar). On an inverted microscope cells were bathed in (in millimolar): 120 Hepes, 70 gluconic acid, 100 trimethylammonium hydroxide, 2 calcium gluconate, 1 magnesium gluconate (pH 7.3). Pipettes were filled with (in millimolar): 100 MES, 60 gluconic acid, 90 trimethylammonium hydroxide, 10 EGTA, 1 glucose, 1 magnesium gluconate, 3.3 magnesium ATP, 0.07 lithium GTP (pH 5.3). Junction potentials at the electrodes were measured, zeroed, and carefully observed for stability. Noted instabilities were smaller than ±2 mV. With these solutions pipette resistance was ∼8 MΩ. After establishing the whole cell configuration the membrane potential was continuously clamped to –50 mV and pulsed every 14 s for 6 s to 20 mV. The access resistance (Ra) and the cell membrane capacitance (Cm) were measured by fitting the current transients caused by a 10-mV pulse with a single exponential. Current-voltage step protocols from –80 mV to +40 mV were applied, and resulting step-currents were recorded. Time constants of current activation (τ) during voltage pulses were fitted with a single exponential of the form I(t) = A · e(–t/τ) + K, where t is time, I(t) is the time-dependent current, A is the amplitude of the current transient, and K is a constant current offset. Whole cell conductance was calculated from steady-state currents as the chord conductance measured between –50 mV and +20 mV. For the calculation of the specific membrane conductance (Gm in picosiemens (pS)/picofarad (pF)) the whole cell conductance was corrected for Ra (on average, 22 ± 5 mΩ (hTE) and 30 ± 3 mΩ (Calu-3)) and normalized to Cm with Gm = (Gc–1 – Ra)–1·Cm–1. Patch clamp recordings and fits were done using pClamp 8 (Axon Instruments, Fremont, CA). Currents during current-voltage step protocols were sampled at 500 Hz and filtered at 200 Hz. For the plots in the figures, currents are shown sampled at 50 Hz by averaging adjacent samples. In the figures original currents are shown without leak subtraction or corrections. Measurements were done at 26 °C. Quantification of Proton Secretion—Proton secretion was measured using the pH-stat titration technique in an Ussing chamber as described previously (13Fischer H. Widdicombe J.H. Illek B. Am. J. Physiol. 2002; 282: C736-C743Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). Briefly, cultures were bathed serosally with Hepes-buffered solution and mucosally with buffer-free solution (3 ml each). Solutions were constantly gassed with oxygen and were nominally free of HCO–3/CO2. Standard NaCl Ringer solutions contained (in millimolar): mucosal, 140 NaCl, 2 KCl, 15 glucose, 2 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2; serosal, 140 NaCl, 2 KCl, 5 glucose, 10 Hepes, 2 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2 (pH 7.3) with HCl/NaOH. During the experiment the pH of the mucosal solution was continuously measured and titrated to a target value of pH 7.3 (range, 7.25–7.35) with 10 mm NaOH to determine H+ secretion (JH) by the cultures. Rates are expressed in nmol·h–1·cm–2, and positive rates refer to acidification of the mucosal medium. Measurements were done at 37 °C. Molecular Expression of NADPH Oxidase Subunits—Total RNA was prepared from 2 × 105 hTE and Calu-3 cells, respectively, grown on permeable filter supports, and poly(A) mRNA was isolated using the RNeasy and Oligotex mRNA kits (Qiagen, Valencia, CA). Reverse transcriptase-PCR was performed using 100 ng of mRNA, 40 units of avian myeloblastosis virus reverse transcriptase, 20 units of RNase inhibitor, 4 μl of 5× buffer (Roche Applied Science), 2 μl of 5 mm dNTP, and 2.5 μm random hexamer oligonucleotides (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA) for 60 min at 42 °C. One microliter of first strand cDNA was used as template in polymerase chain reactions with NADPH oxidase-specific oligonucleotides (see Table I). PCR was performed in a DNA thermal cycler using AmpliTaq Gold® DNA polymerase (Applied Biosystems). Following a 10-min 94 °C incubation, reactions proceeded for 30 s at 94 °C then 60 s at 60 °C for 43 cycles followed by 7 min at 72 °C. One-tenth of the amplification products were analyzed on a 1% agarose gel. For quantitative PCR total RNA was isolated from hTE and analyzed using an ABI Prizm 7700 sequence detection system (PE Applied Biosystems, Inc.). Proteins were separated by 6% SDS-PAGE and transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane. The membrane was blocked with 1% casein and probed with a rabbit anti-Duox antibody (kindly provided by F. Miot (22De Deken X. Wang D. Many M.-C. Costagliola S. Libert F. Vassart G. Dumont J.E. Miot F. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 23227-23233Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (489) Google Scholar)), and horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary anti-rabbit antibody labeling was visualized using the ECL Western blotting analysis system (Amersham Biosciences). For immunocytochemistry, hTE cells were dissected from confluent cultures, fixed with 2% paraformaldehyde, and incubated with 0.3% (v/v) Triton X-100 followed by 1% (w/v) bovine serum albumin in phosphate-buffered saline. Cells were immunostained for Duox, and the tight junction protein ZO-1 was used as a marker of the apical region using a monoclonal anti-ZO-1 antibody (BD Biosciences). Secondary antibodies were Alexa Fluor 488 anti-rabbit (Molecular Probes) for Duox and Alexa Fluor 546 anti-mouse for ZO-1. Cells were embedded in Crystal Mount (Biomedia) and observed with a 63×/1.4 numerical aperture oil-immersion objective on a Solamere spinning disc confocal microscope (excitation, 457 nm; emission, 535 ± 20 nm for Duox, and excitation, 514 nm; emission, 605 ± 30 nm for ZO-1). Measurement of Intracellular pH (pHi)—Cells on glass coverslips were incubated for 30 min with 20 μm BCECF-AM (2′,7′-bis-(2-carboxyethyl)-5-(and-6)-carboxyfluorescein, acetoxymethyl ester, Molecular Probes Inc.), washed, and allowed to cleave the dye for 60 min. Cellular fluorescence was investigated in an open perfusion chamber on an inverted microscope. Excitation wavelengths were 440 and 495 nm, and emission was collected between 525 and 550 nm with a cooled charge-coupled device camera (Photometrics CoolSnap HQ, Roper Scientific) controlled by a computerized imaging system (Metafluor, Universal Imaging Corp.). Emission intensities of individual cells were background-subtracted, and ratios of 495 to 440 nm were calculated. pHi was calculated from ratios using a four-point pH calibration in presence of 20 μm nigericin in KCl solution. Calibration points were pH 7.5, 7, 6.5, and 6.0. Resulting calibration ratios for individual cells were fitted to second order polynomials, and fitted parameters were used to calculate pHi from measured ratios. Individual rates of acidification of cells during the first 15 min of treatment with amiloride were determined by linear regression. Dye loading and experiments were done at 26 °C. NaCl solution composition was (in millimolar) 145 NaCl, 5 KCl, 1 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2, 12.5 Hepes (pH 7.4). pH calibration was performed in (in millimolar) 5 NaCl, 145 KCl, 1 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2, and Hepes and/or MES (total buffer 12.5 mm). Statistics—Data are presented as original values or as mean ± S.E.; n refers to the number of cells or tissues investigated. Effects were tested with t tests or with ANOVAs followed by Bonferroni-corrected t tests. Calculations were done with StatView (Abacus Concepts, Berkeley, CA). Calculated p values are given, and p < 0.05 was considered significant. Proton Conductances in Airway Cells—Single hTE and Calu-3 cells were whole cell patch-clamped to characterize and compare their H+ conductance under conditions selective for H+ currents with a pipette to bath pH gradient of 5.3 to 7.3. Calu-3 are large round cells with an average Cm of 29.9 ± 5.9 pF (n = 7). hTE were visibly smaller with a Cm of 10.4 ± 1.4 pF (n = 6, significantly lower than Calu-3, p = 0.012, t test). hTE had visible cilia on one pole of the elongated cells. Reported conductances were normalized to Cm to account for the difference in cell size. Measured currents were identified as H+ currents by the established characteristics: (i) H+-selective reversal potentials, (ii) zinc sensitivity, and (iii) activation by depolarization with time constants in the order of seconds (34DeCoursey T.E. Morgan D. Cherny V.V. J. Gen. Physiol. 2002; 120: 773-779Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). Both airway cell types expressed whole cell H+ currents, H+-selective reversal potentials, and activation by depolarizing pulses. Continuous H+ current recordings and block by ZnSO4 are shown in Fig. 1A for hTE and Fig. 1B for Calu-3. During the recordings the membrane potential was clamped to –50 mV and pulsed to 20 mV (as shown in the voltage traces, lower panels of Fig. 1, A and B) to continuously monitor the depolarization activation of H+ currents. Note the typically slow current activation during the pulses in both cell types. Addition of 100 μm ZnSO4 to the bath fully blocked the depolarization-activated currents. The current responses to the voltage step protocols from Fig. 1 (A and B) are shown in detail in Fig. 1 (C and D) for both cell types before (top panels) and after (bottom panels) addition of 100 μm ZnSO4. Outward H+ currents activated slowly during depolarizing potentials and were blocked after addition of ZnSO4. Steady-state current-voltage relations are shown in Fig. 2 (E and F). Current-voltage relations recorded under control conditions (triangles) showed outward rectification and negative reversal potentials indicative for H+ currents. Control steady-state currents reversed at –21.6 ± 4.7 mV (hTE) and –25.9 ± 6.1 mV (Calu-3). Addition of Zn2+ shifted the reversal potential to positive values in both cell types (Fig. 1, E and F, circles, by on average 37.8 ± 3.5 mV, n = 11; not different between cell types). On average, hTE and Calu-3 expressed similar specific H+ conductances of 19.6 ± 3.1 pS/pF and 11.6 ± 2.8 pS/pF, respectively (p = 0.085, Fig. 1G).Fig. 2Time constants of voltage-activated H+ currents. A and B, membrane potential was stepped from –50 to 20 mV or 40 mV (as indicated) in hTE (A) or Calu-3 (B). Dots are sampled current data; the line shows the best fit to a single exponential function; the width of samples is 20 ms. Fitted time constants are: hTE, τ40 = 2.23 s, τ20 = 3.14 s; Calu-3, from τ40 = 3.68 s, τ20 = 6.9 s. C, average time constants during depolarizing pulses –50 mV to 20 mV or to 40 mV as indicated. Time constants were not different between cell types (p = 0.1) but τ20 (3.9 ± 0.5 s) was significantly longer than τ40 (2.8 ± 0.4 ms, p = 0.01, two-way ANOVA, n = 6 hTE and n = 7 Calu-3).View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) As a biophysical identifier of the H+ conductance we used the time constants of current activation when stepping the membrane potential from –50 mV to 20 mV (τ20) and from –50 mV to 40 mV (τ40). Fig. 2 shows current activations evoked by voltage pulses in hTE (Fig. 2A) and Calu-3 (Fig. 2B). In both cell types the depolarization-activated currents were fitted well with a single exponential (lines in Fig. 2, A and B) yielding τ20 and τ40 (Fig. 2C). Fitted time constants at either potential were not different between cell types (p > 0.4, t tests) suggesting that hTE and Calu-3 cells expressed a biophysically similar type of H+ conductance. On average τ20 = 3.97 ± 0.52 s and τ40 = 2.77 ± 0.39 s. τ20 was significantly longer than τ40 (p = 0.01), consistent with a voltage-activated opening transition. For comparison, the native H+ conductance of rat alveolar cells (τ40 = 2.5 s (35Cherny V.V. DeCoursey T.E. J. Gen. Physiol. 1999; 114: 819-838Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar)) or eosinophils (τ40 = 2.4 s (36Banfi B. Schrenzel J. Nusse O. Lew D.P. Ligeti E. Krause K.-H. Demaurex N. J. Exp. Med. 1999; 190: 183-194Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar)) showed values similar to our data under comparable recording conditions. These data showed that hTE and Calu-3 cells expressed functionally similar H+ conductances, as judged by the quantitatively similar average conductances, rates of voltage-activated currents, and zinc sensitivity. Acid Secretion by hTE and Calu-3 Cultures—Acid secretion of intact epithelia was measured using the pH-stat titration technique in Ussing chambers. Block of H+ channels (by ZnCl2) and block of NADPH oxidase (by acetovanillone or AEBSF) was used to 1) determine the role of H+ channels in epithelial acid secretion, 2) verify an apical location of H+ channels in polarized epithelial monolayers, and 3) determine the role of NADPH oxidase during acid secretion. Both cell types showed basal acid secretion into the mucosal compartment. In hTE, JH = 939 ± 49 nmol·h–1·cm–2, n = 12. Calu-3 showed a 9-fold smaller JH of 106 ± 9 nmol·h–1·cm–2, n = 18 (p < 0.0001, Fig. 3). When cultures were pre-treated for 1 h with ZnCl2 (100 μm mucosally), acid secretion by hTE was significantly reduced (to 480 ± 29 nmol·h–1·cm–2, n = 6, p < 0.0001, unpaired t test). In contrast, no significant effect of ZnCl2 was found on acid secretion by Calu-3 (block to 84 ± 4 nmol·h–1·cm–2, n = 5, p = 0.2, Fig. 3). In addition we tested the NADPH oxidase blockers AEBSF and acetovanillone (500 μm each) on H+ secretion by hTE and Calu-3. After incubation of cultures for 14–16 h with blockers, H+ secretion was inhibited significantly in hTE (p < 0.0001, ANOVA) but not in Calu-3 (Fig. 2). In hTE, AEBSF reduced JH to 515 ± 49 nmol·h–1·cm–2, and acetovanillone reduced JH to 606 ± 58 nmol·h–1·cm–2. These values were not different from inhibition of acid secretion achieved with ZnCl2. The remaining H+ secretion in hTE was partially blocked by apical ouabain (50 μm, by 15 ± 5.8%, n = 7, different from zero, p = 0.04) and apical bafilomycin A1 (100 nm, by 11 ± 3.9%, n = 7, different from zero, p = 0.04) indicating that hTE expressed additional mechanisms for acid secretion (12Coakley R.D. Nitrosamine 4-(methylnitrosamino)-1-(3-pyridyl)-1-butanone (NNK) is formed by nitrosation of nicotine and has been identified as the most potent carcinogen contained in cigarette smoke. NNK significantly contributes to smoking-related lung cancer, but the molecular mechanism remains enigmatic. Bcl2 and c-Myc are two major oncogenic proteins that cooperatively promote tumor development. We report here that NNK simultaneously stimulates Bcl2 phosphorylation exclusively at Ser70 and c-Myc at Thr58 and Ser62 through activation of both ERK1/2 and PKCα, which is required for NNK-induced survival and proliferation of human lung cancer cells. Treatment of cells with staurosporine or PD98059 blocks both Bcl2 and c-Myc phosphorylation and results in suppression of NNK-induced proliferation. Specific depletion of c-Myc expression by RNA interference retards G1/S cell cycle transition and blocks NNK-induced cell proliferation. Phosphorylation of Bcl2 at Ser70 promotes a direct interaction between Bcl2 and c-Myc in the nucleus and on the outer mitochondrial membrane that significantly enhances the half-life of the c-Myc protein. Thus, NNK-induced functional cooperation of Bcl2 and c-Myc in promoting cell survival and proliferation may occur in a novel mechanism involving their phosphorylation, which may lead to development of human lung cancer and/or chemoresistance. Nitrosamine 4-(methylnitrosamino)-1-(3-pyridyl)-1-butanone (NNK) is formed by nitrosation of nicotine and has been identified as the most potent carcinogen contained in cigarette smoke. NNK significantly contributes to smoking-related lung cancer, but the molecular mechanism remains enigmatic. Bcl2 and c-Myc are two major oncogenic proteins that cooperatively promote tumor development. We report here that NNK simultaneously stimulates Bcl2 phosphorylation exclusively at Ser70 and c-Myc at Thr58 and Ser62 through activation of both ERK1/2 and PKCα, which is required for NNK-induced survival and proliferation of human lung cancer cells. Treatment of cells with staurosporine or PD98059 blocks both Bcl2 and c-Myc phosphorylation and results in suppression of NNK-induced proliferation. Specific depletion of c-Myc expression by RNA interference retards G1/S cell cycle transition and blocks NNK-induced cell proliferation. Phosphorylation of Bcl2 at Ser70 promotes a direct interaction between Bcl2 and c-Myc in the nucleus and on the outer mitochondrial membrane that significantly enhances the half-life of the c-Myc protein. Thus, NNK-induced functional cooperation of Bcl2 and c-Myc in promoting cell survival and proliferation may occur in a novel mechanism involving their phosphorylation, which may lead to development of human lung cancer and/or chemoresistance. Lung cancer is the predominant cause of cancer deaths worldwide, with a high mortality rate and a five year survival rate of 15% (1Parker S.L. Tong T. Bolden S. Wingo P.A. CA-Cancer J. Clin. 1997; 47: 5-27Crossref PubMed Scopus (2335) Google Scholar). Cigarette smoking is the most important risk factor in the development of lung cancer (2Stellman S.D. Takezaki T. Wang L. Chen Y. Citron M.L. Djordjevic M.V. Harlap S. Muscat J.E. Neugut A.I. Wynder E.L. Ogawa H. Tajima K. Aoki K. Cancer Epidemiol. Biomarkers Prev. 2001; 10: 1193-1199PubMed Google Scholar). About 90% of male and 75-80% of female lung cancer deaths are caused by smoking each year in the United States (3Hecht S.S. J. Natl. Cancer Inst. 1999; 91: 1194-1210Crossref PubMed Scopus (1578) Google Scholar). Cigarette smoke contains about 4,000 chemicals, 55 of which have been evaluated as carcinogens (3Hecht S.S. J. Natl. Cancer Inst. 1999; 91: 1194-1210Crossref PubMed Scopus (1578) Google Scholar). Nitrosamine 4-(methylnitrosamino)-1-(3-pyridyl)-1-butanone (NNK), 1The abbreviations used are: NNK, nitrosamine 4-(methylnitrosamino)-1-(3-pyridyl)-1-butanone; SCLC, small cell lung cancer; nAChR, nicotinic acetylcholine receptor; PKC, protein kinase c; MAPK, mitogen-activated protein kinase; ERK, extracellular signal-regulated kinase; α-BTX, α-bungarotoxin; siRNA, small interfering RNA; MEK, MAPK/ERK kinase; JNK, c-Jun N-terminal kinase; WT, wild type; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; AA, T58A/S62A. 1The abbreviations used are: NNK, nitrosamine 4-(methylnitrosamino)-1-(3-pyridyl)-1-butanone; SCLC, small cell lung cancer; nAChR, nicotinic acetylcholine receptor; PKC, protein kinase c; MAPK, mitogen-activated protein kinase; ERK, extracellular signal-regulated kinase; α-BTX, α-bungarotoxin; siRNA, small interfering RNA; MEK, MAPK/ERK kinase; JNK, c-Jun N-terminal kinase; WT, wild type; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; AA, T58A/S62A. a nicotine-nitrosated derivative, has been identified as the most potent lung carcinogen (4Hecht S.S. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 1998; 11: 559-603Crossref PubMed Scopus (967) Google Scholar, 5Hoffmann D. Rivenson A. Hecht S.S. Crit. Rev. Toxicol. 1996; 26: 199-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). Cigarette smoke contains a substantial amount of NNK, and the total dose experienced by a smoker in a lifetime of smoking is remarkably close to the lowest dose shown to induce lung cancer in rats (5Hoffmann D. Rivenson A. Hecht S.S. Crit. Rev. Toxicol. 1996; 26: 199-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). Therefore, NNK is considered to be a major contributor to lung carcinogenesis in smokers (6Schuller H.M. Nat. Rev. 2002; 2: 455-463Crossref Scopus (162) Google Scholar, 7Schuller H.M. Plummer H.K. Jull B.A. Anat. Rec. 2003; 270: 51-58Crossref Scopus (81) Google Scholar).It has been demonstrated that NNK induces DNA damage, including single-strand DNA breaks, alkylphosphotriester formation (8Cloutier J.F. Drouin R. Weinfeld M. O'Connor T.R. Castonguay A. J. Mol. Biol. 2001; 313: 539-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar), DNA adduct formation, increased oxidative stress (9Bhagwat S.V. Vijayasarathy C. Raza H. Mullick J. Avadhani N.G. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1998; 56: 831-839Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar), as well as induction of p53 and Ras mutations (6Schuller H.M. Nat. Rev. 2002; 2: 455-463Crossref Scopus (162) Google Scholar, 8Cloutier J.F. Drouin R. Weinfeld M. O'Connor T.R. Castonguay A. J. Mol. Biol. 2001; 313: 539-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). Traditional views have emphasized the formation of promutagenic DNA adducts from reactive metabolites of NNK (10Hecht S.S. Crit. Rev. Toxicol. 1996; 26: 163-181Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar) and resulting point mutations in the k-Ras gene (11Belinsky S.A. Devereux T.R. Anderson M.W. Mutat. Res. 1990; 233: 105-116Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar) as important mediators of smoking-associated lung carcinogenesis. However, k-Ras mutations are absent in small cell lung cancer (SCLC; Ref. 12Mitsudomi T. Viallet J. Mulshine J.L. Linnoila R.I. Minna J.D. Gazdar A.F. Oncogene. 1991; 6: 1353-1362PubMed Google Scholar). The lack of these mutations strongly suggests that the development of SCLC may be caused by cellular events other than Ras mutations. In the search for potential mechanisms of SCLC development, our studies focus on the role of NNK-associated signal transduction pathways.In addition to DNA damage, the mechanisms that promote cellular survival and proliferation may be the critical steps in NNK-initiated carcinogenesis. NNK, a nicotine-nitrosated carcinogenic derivative, retains some structural similarities with nicotine and binds to the α7-nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (α7 nAChR), resulting in the influx of Ca2+, release of 5-hydroxytryptamine, and activation of a protein kinase cascade (i.e. PKC/Raf-1/MEK/ERK1/2; Refs. 6Schuller H.M. Nat. Rev. 2002; 2: 455-463Crossref Scopus (162) Google Scholar and 7Schuller H.M. Plummer H.K. Jull B.A. Anat. Rec. 2003; 270: 51-58Crossref Scopus (81) Google Scholar). However, the downstream survival and proliferative substrates of NNK-activated protein kinases have not been identified.Among the known proto-oncogenes, the cellular Myc gene (c-Myc) is one of those most frequently implicated in carcinogenesis (13Bissonnette R.P. Echeverri F. Mahboubi A. Green D.R. Nature. 1992; 359: 552-554Crossref PubMed Scopus (922) Google Scholar, 14Soucie E.L. Annis M.G. Sedivy J. Filmus J. Leber B. Andrews D.W. Penn L.Z. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 4725-4736Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar, 15Hanahan D. Weinberg R.A. Cell. 2000; 100: 57-70Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21899) Google Scholar). Deregulated expression of the structurally unaltered Myc protein is sufficient to drive continuous cell proliferation and apoptosis in response to growth-promoting and growth-inhibitory signals, respectively (14Soucie E.L. Annis M.G. Sedivy J. Filmus J. Leber B. Andrews D.W. Penn L.Z. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 4725-4736Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). Expression of c-Myc can initiate proliferation and increase sensitivity to apoptosis under low serum conditions when antiapoptotic mechanisms are not activated (16Evan G.I. Wyllie A.H. Gilbert C.S. Littlewood T.D. Land H. Brooks M. Waters C.M. Penn L.Z. Hancock D.C. Cell. 1992; 69: 119-128Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2764) Google Scholar). Bcl2 and c-Myc are two major oncogenic proteins that can functionally cooperate in cell proliferation, transformation, apoptosis, and tumorigenesis (17Reed J.C. Cuddy M. Haldar S. Croce C. Nowell P. Makover D. Bradley K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 3660-3664Crossref PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar). To avoid c-Myc-induced cell death and ensure continuous cell proliferation, Bcl2 functions as one of the most potent Myc-cooperating oncoproteins (13Bissonnette R.P. Echeverri F. Mahboubi A. Green D.R. Nature. 1992; 359: 552-554Crossref PubMed Scopus (922) Google Scholar, 18Fanidi A. Harrington E.A. Evan G.I. Nature. 1992; 359: 554-556Crossref PubMed Scopus (702) Google Scholar), which is a global inhibitor of apoptosis, likely through multiple mechanisms (14Soucie E.L. Annis M.G. Sedivy J. Filmus J. Leber B. Andrews D.W. Penn L.Z. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 4725-4736Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar, 19Deng X. Ruvolo P. Carr B. May Jr., W.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 1578-1583Crossref PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar). Bcl2 can specifically abrogate c-Myc-induced apoptosis without affecting the c-Myc mitogenic function (18Fanidi A. Harrington E.A. Evan G.I. Nature. 1992; 359: 554-556Crossref PubMed Scopus (702) Google Scholar). However, the molecular mechanism by which Bcl2 cooperates with c-Myc remains unclear. Because both Bcl2 and c-Myc are expressed in SCLC and non-SCLC cells (20Ikegaki N. Katsumata M. Minna J. Tsujimoto Y. Cancer Res. 1994; 54: 6-8PubMed Google Scholar, 21Bepler G. Bading H. Heimann B. Kiefer P. Havemann K. Moelling K. Oncogene. 1989; 4: 45-50PubMed Google Scholar), these two oncoproteins may be regulated by NNK-activated signal pathways in human lung cancer cells. NNK may facilitate a functional cooperation between Bcl2 and c-Myc that contributes to lung cancer development and proliferation of tumor cells.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESMaterials—NNK was purchased from Toronto Research Chemicals (Toronto, Canada). Anti-Bcl2, c-Myc, PKCα, ERK1, ERK2, JNK1, p38, and phospho-specific ERK, p38 antibodies were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology (Santa Cruz, CA). The T58/S62 dual phosphospecific c-Myc antibody was obtained from Cell Signaling Technology. Cisplatin was obtained from Sigma. PD98059, staurosporine, and the α7 nAChR-specific inhibitor α-bungarotoxin (α-BTX) were purchased from Calbiochem (San Diego, CA). NCI-H69 and NCI-H82 cell lines and human Bcl2 cDNA were obtained from ATCC (Manassas, VA). The c-Myc short interfering RNA (siRNA) and Silencer™ siRNA transfection kit were purchased from Ambion Inc. (Austin, TX). Cell proliferation assay kit WST-1 was purchased from Roche Applied Science. c-Myc cDNA was obtained from Dr. Zajac-Kaye Maria (NCI, National Institutes of Health). Proteinase K was purchased from Invitrogen. All of the reagents used were obtained from commercial sources unless otherwise stated.Cell Lines, Plasmids, and Transfections—NCI-H82, NCI-H69, and H1299 cells were maintained in RPMI 1640 with 10% fetal bovine serum. Nucleotides corresponding to each serine or threonine residue in Bcl2 or c-Myc cDNA were substituted to create a conservative alteration to alanine or glutamine with a site-directed mutagenesis kit (Clontech). Each single mutant was confirmed by sequencing of the cDNA and was then cloned into the pCIneo (Promega) or pcDNA3.1 (Invitrogen) mammalian expression vector. The pCIneo plasmid containing each Bcl2 mutant cDNA was transfected into NCI-H82 cells by electroporation. Clones stably expressing WT or mutant Bcl2 were selected in a medium containing G418 (0.6 mg/ml). The expression levels of exogenous Bcl2 were compared by Western blot analysis. Three separate clones for each mutant expressing similar amounts of exogenous Bcl2 were selected for further analysis. The pcDNA3.1 plasmids bearing WT or T58A/S62A (AA) c-Myc mutant were transfected into H1299 cells using LipofectAMINE™ 2000 according to the manufacturer's instructions (Invitrogen). The expression levels of exogenous c-Myc were analyzed by Western blot analysis using c-Myc antibody.Protein Isolation—The cells were washed with 1× PBS and resuspended in ice-cold EBC buffer (0.5% Nonidet P-40, 50 mm Tris, pH 7.6, 120 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, and 1 mm β-mercaptoethanol) with protease inhibitor mixture set I (Calbiochem). The cells were lysed by sonication and centrifuged at 14,000 × g for 10 min at 4 °C. The resulting supernatant was collected as the total cell lysate as described (22Chen G. Lee E.Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 33693-33697Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar).Metabolic Labeling, Immunoprecipitation, and Western Blot Analysis—The cells were washed with phosphate-free RPMI medium and metabolically labeled with [32P]orthophosphoric acid for 90 min. After agonist or inhibitor addition, the cells were washed with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline and lysed in detergent buffer. Bcl2 was then immunoprecipitated as described previously (19Deng X. Ruvolo P. Carr B. May Jr., W.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 1578-1583Crossref PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar, 23Ito T. Deng X. Carr B. May W.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 11671-11673Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (494) Google Scholar). The samples were subjected to 10-20% gradient SDS-PAGE, transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane, and exposed to Kodak X-Omat film for the times indicated at -80 °C. Bcl2 phosphorylation was determined by autoradiography. The same filter was then probed by Western blotting analysis with a Bcl2 antibody and developed using an ECL Kit (Amersham Biosciences) as described previously (23Ito T. Deng X. Carr B. May W.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 11671-11673Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (494) Google Scholar).Pulse-Chase Analysis of the c-Myc Half-Life—The cells were metabolically labeled with [35S]methionine for 60 min. The [35S]methionine-labeled cells were washed and incubated in fresh methionine replete RPMI 1640 medium for various time points up to 60 min. The cells were harvested at each time point, washed with ice-cold PBS, and lysed in EBC buffer, and 35S-labeled-c-Myc was immunoprecipitated using c-Myc antibody. The Bcl2-associated c-Myc (i.e. Bound c-Myc) was coimmunoprecipitated using Bcl2 antibody, and the unbound c-Myc was then immunoprecipitated with c-Myc antibody from the same lysate. The samples were subjected to 10-20% gradient SDS-PAGE. The half-life of c-Myc was determined by electronic autoradiography as described (24Deng X. Gao F. Flagg T. May W.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2004; 101: 153-158Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar).Assay of PKCα Activity and Phosphorylation of c-Myc and Bcl2 in Vitro—PKCα was immunoprecipitated from cell lysates with PKCα antibody following treatment with NNK. Immunoprecipitated PKCα was suspended in 50 μl of kinase assay buffer containing 20 mm Hepes, pH 7.4, 100 μm CaCl2, 10 mm MgCl2, 200 μg/ml histone-1, 100 μm ATP, 100 μg/ml phosphatidylserine, 2 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP, and 0.03% Triton X-100. The mixture was incubated for 30 min at 30 °C. The reaction was stopped by the addition of 2× SDS sample buffer and boiling the sample for 5 min. The samples were separated by SDS-PAGE. The activities of PKCα were determined by autoradiography. To assess phosphorylation of Bcl2 and c-Myc in vitro, Bcl2 or c-Myc was immunoprecipitated from cell lysates using Bcl2 or c-Myc antibody, respectively. The immune complex was then incubated with purified, activated PKCα (Panvera, Madison, WI), ERK1, or ERK2 (Calbiochem) in assay buffer containing [γ-32P]ATP as described previously (19Deng X. The potent human pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis persists in macrophages within a specialized, immature phagosome by interfering with the pathway of phagolysosome biogenesis. The molecular mechanisms underlying this process remain to be fully elucidated. Here, using four-dimensional microscopy, we detected on model phagosomes, which normally mature into phagolysosomes, the existence of cyclical waves of phosphatidylinositol 3-phosphate (PI3P), a membrane trafficking regulatory lipid essential for phagosomal acquisition of lysosomal characteristics. We show that mycobacteria interfere with the dynamics of PI3P on phagosomal organelles by altering the timing and characteristics of the PI3P waves on phagosomes. The default program of cyclical PI3P waves on model phagosomes is composed of an initial stage (phase I), represented by a strong PI3P burst occurring only upon the completion of phagosome formation, and a subsequent stage (phase II) of recurring PI3P waves on maturing phagosomes with the average periodicity of 20 min. Mycobacteria alter this program in two ways: (i) by inducing, in a cholesterol-dependent fashion, a neophase I* of premature PI3P production, coinciding with the process of mycobacterial entry into the macrophage, and (ii) by inhibiting the calmodulin-dependent phase II responsible for the acquisition of lysosomal characteristics. We conclude that the default pathway of phagosomal maturation into the phagolysosome includes temporally organized cyclical waves of PI3P on phagosomal membranes and that this process is targeted for reprogramming by mycobacteria as they prevent phagolysosome formation. The molecular mechanisms underlying this process remain to be fully elucidated. Here, using four-dimensional microscopy, we detected on model phagosomes, which normally mature into phagolysosomes, the existence of cyclical waves of phosphatidylinositol 3-phosphate (PI3P), a membrane trafficking regulatory lipid essential for phagosomal acquisition of lysosomal characteristics. We show that mycobacteria interfere with the dynamics of PI3P on phagosomal organelles by altering the timing and characteristics of the PI3P waves on phagosomes. The default program of cyclical PI3P waves on model phagosomes is composed of an initial stage (phase I), represented by a strong PI3P burst occurring only upon the completion of phagosome formation, and a subsequent stage (phase II) of recurring PI3P waves on maturing phagosomes with the average periodicity of 20 min. Mycobacteria alter this program in two ways: (i) by inducing, in a cholesterol-dependent fashion, a neophase I* of premature PI3P production, coinciding with the process of mycobacterial entry into the macrophage, and (ii) by inhibiting the calmodulin-dependent phase II responsible for the acquisition of lysosomal characteristics. We conclude that the default pathway of phagosomal maturation into the phagolysosome includes temporally organized cyclical waves of PI3P on phagosomal membranes and that this process is targeted for reprogramming by mycobacteria as they prevent phagolysosome formation. Phagocytosis is a fundamental biological process essential for proper tissue homeostasis, development, elimination of invading microorganisms, and processing of antigens for presentation to the immune system. The role in phagosomal maturation of phosphoinositide-interacting regulators of trafficking, such as EEA1, underscores the significance of phosphatidylinositol (PI) derivatives in phagosome and phagolysosome biogenesis. PI derivatives regulate diverse trafficking processes by affecting the localization and activity of effector proteins containing lipid binding modules such as C2, ENTH, FERM, FYVE, PH, and PX domains (29Lemmon M.A. Traffic. 2003; 4: 201-213Crossref PubMed Scopus (479) Google Scholar). A subset of PI derivatives and lipid-binding proteins also plays a role in phagocytosis and phagolysosome biogenesis. Phagocytosis triggers production of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2), which recruits actin to the phagocytic cup; this is followed by disappearance of PIP2 as the phagosome seals (9Botelho R.J.
